Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Improved Mass Spectrometry Identification and Quantification Through Probabilistic Data Segmentation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mass spectrometry is a chemistry technique that has a broad range of applications of societal interest, including in medicine, forensics, and basic biological sciences. This research develops new analysis techniques that allow mass spectrometry data to be used in ways that are not currently possible, that may lead to advances in fields like medical diagnostics, drug development, and better understanding of poorly understood ailments involving proteins, such as Alzheimer's disease. A significant part of the research plan involves outreach to Seeley Swan High School in Montana, where researchers and teachers will team up to teach students problem-solving skills using computers, in subjects such as chemistry, math, and biology. Students who have strong computational problem-solving abilities are more likely to attend college and more likely to apply for, and succeed in, professions requiring those skills, including scientific research.

Mass spectrometry (MS) plays a role in many investigations because it can quantify and identify the major components (proteins, lipids, metabolites) of almost any cellular system. MS data processing identifies the molecular composition of an MS sample by analyzing digital MS output signals. This research develops a fundamentally different approach to MS output signal analysis by: 1) Creating a fundamentally different paradigm for MS signal processing that probabilistically segments the entire MS output file instead of extracting subregions of interest, 2) Showing that current methods are insufficient through a quantitative evaluation, 3) Enabling future research by capturing currently excluded low abundance molecules, and 4) Demonstrating how this new paradigm broadens downstream experimental possibilities with a novel correspondence approach built on the additional information provided by the proposed segmentation techniques. Diversity will be fostered through continuing and expanding currently successful recruitment practices for lab participation. This research brings real research experience into collegiate and rural high school classrooms by 1) Stimulating discovery (particularly among underrepresented groups) through integrating computational mass spectrometry into the undergraduate and graduate computer science curriculum at the University of Montana. 2) Fostering problem-based STEM experience in rural high school students through integrating computational problem solving research into high school course materials. Results from this research will be posted to http://ms.cs.umt.edu.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mass spectrometry (MS) data analysis provides critical information to many tasks in many fields with high human impact, including the design and testing of drugs. Challenges to MS data analysis include the extreme complexity and volume of the data.

This award enabled the Dr. Smith?s group to develop a first-of-its-kind software for fast human annotation and viewing of mass spectrometry data. The software included novel approaches to storing and retrieving the vast volumes of data in these experiments as well as novel interfaces and tools designed to minimize the amount of human time required to produce annotated data sets. Through the creation and application of four annotated public data sets, the group was able to design two new algorithms for signal extraction from mass spectrometry data sets and demonstrate, in the first quantitative evaluations of these two classes of MS data processing algorithms, that the novel algorithms outperformed other available algorithms. 

These contributions were made possible through the recruitment, support, and successful graduation of four graduate students, two of whom were female, and two of whom came from a different undergraduate field. The development of new research-themed modules in introductory computer science coursework, which helped recruit the dozens of first-time undergraduate researchers who participated in this project, two of whom became graduate students on the project. 

The research findings were published in eight peer-reviewed publications in high impact venues, with fifteen co-authored publication opportunities for students, as well as twelve posters at conference, all with student co-authors.

A five-year annual guest lecture series at a rural high school provided regular interactions with small groups of high school students which introduced hundreds of students to college, research, computer science, and bioinformatics.

Modified by: Rob Smith

Through the creation and application of four annotated public data sets, the group was able to design two new algorithms for signal extraction from mass spectrometry data sets and demonstrate, in the first quantitative evaluations of these two classes of MS data processing algorithms, that the novel algorithms outperformed other available algorithms. These contributions were made possible through the recruitment, support, and successful graduation of four graduate students, two of whom were female, and two of whom came from a different undergraduate field. The development of new research-themed modules in introductory computer science coursework, which helped recruit the dozens of first-time undergraduate researchers who participated in this project, two of whom became graduate students on the project. The research findings were published in eight peer-reviewed publications in high impact venues, with fifteen co-authored publication opportunities for students, as well as twelve posters at conference, all with student co-authors.
